verses.text: In my distress I called to the LORD, and He answered me.
verses.comment: This verse opens with a prayerful cry to the LORD in a time of trouble. It reminds us that God hears those who call on Him in sincerity and faith, an idea picked up throughout the Psalms and fulfilled supremely in Christ, who intercedes for us (Heb. 7:25).

verses.text: LORD, deliver my soul from lying lips, from a deceitful tongue.
verses.comment: A plea for protection from falsehood and slander. The theme of truth versus lies is central, reflecting the need for purity not only of speech but of heart, prefiguring the call to inner transformation in the New Testament (Matt. 5:8).

verses.text: What shall be given to you, and what more shall be done to you, you deceitful tongue?
verses.comment: The psalmist asks rhetorically about the consequences awaiting those who practice deceit. This reflects both temporal and eternal justice, foreshadowing the New Testament warnings about the tongue (Jas. 3:6).

verses.text: Sharp arrows of a warrior, with burning coals of the broom tree.
verses.comment: The imagery of arrows and burning coals pictures God's judgment on deceitfulness. Spiritual interpretation connects this with the discipline needed to purify one's words and intentions, a theme prominent in the apostolic tradition.

verses.text: Woe to me, that I sojourn in Meshech, that I dwell among the tents of Kedar!
verses.comment: Meshech and Kedar symbolize living among people far from God—reflecting the soul's longing for its true home. This foreshadows the New Testament's teaching about Christians as 'sojourners and exiles' in this world (1 Pet. 2:11).

verses.text: For too long my soul has dwelt with those who hate peace.
verses.comment: The psalmist laments the pain of living among those who reject peace—a parallel to the Church's mission to be a sign of true peace in a troubled world, calling believers to unity and reconciliation in Christ (Eph. 2:14).

verses.text: I am for peace, but when I speak, they are for war.
verses.comment: This final verse highlights the contrast between the desire for peace and the conflict in the world. It captures both the suffering of God’s people and the example of Christ, who is the true Prince of Peace (Isa. 9:6; Matt. 5:9). The spiritual interpretation urges unity and the pursuit of reconciliation—key marks of authentic faith.
